M.G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 2.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over the matter under M.G.L. c. 231, § 2, and venue is proper because the Property is located in Brockton, Plymouth County, and the events giving rise to this action occurred in Brockton.

M.G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment, implied by law in all residential leases pursuant to M.G.L. c. 186, § 14, guarantees tenants the right to live in their rental units free from substantial interference.

*Lashley v. Bryant*, 7 Mass. App. Ct. 82.proposition: The lack of hot water for nearly three weeks constitutes a substantial interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment of the Property.
*Lashley v. Bryant*, 7 Mass. App. Ct. 82.case_name: Labor Relations Commission v. City of Everett
*Lashley v. Bryant*, 7 Mass. App. Ct. 82.support_reasoning: The opinion is a public‑sector labor relations case about the Labor Relations Commission’s authority and the procedural route for judicial review, not a landlord‑tenant or quiet enjoyment case. It does not discuss hot water, habitability, residential leases, or any concept of interference with quiet enjoyment of property. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition that a three‑week lack of hot water is a substantial interference with quiet enjoyment.
*Lashley v. Bryant*, 7 Mass. App. Ct. 82.relevant_excerpt: Since the unilateral change instituted by the employer in the hours during which firefighters were required to perform floor patrol was found by the commission to constitute a refusal to bargain collectively in good faith and hence an unfair labor practice under c. 150E, § 10(a)(5), the commission had the power under c. 150E, § 11, to order the employer to make whole those employees who were required to perform additional duties while the mayor’s order was in effect.

*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 851.proposition: Defendant’s failure to take adequate steps to promptly restore hot water constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 851.support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss hot water, utilities, or prompt restoration of services. Its holding is about the level of landlord fault (at least negligence with notice) required to establish a violation of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment, specifically in the context of lead paint. While it cites other cases where failure to repair known defects can violate § 14, it does not itself establish that failure to promptly restore hot water constitutes such a breach.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 851.relevant_excerpt: “We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’ See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so).”

*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.raw_text: *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.proposition: This breach entitles Plaintiff to recover damages, including rent abatements, incidental expenses, and statutory remedies.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion recognizes that a tenant prevailing on a G.L. c. 186, § 14 quiet-enjoyment claim may obtain damages, injunctive relief, costs, and attorney’s fees, but it does not discuss or award specific categories such as rent abatements or incidental expenses, nor does it delineate the measure of damages for that breach. The court mainly addresses liability and available injunctive relief, not a remedial framework including rent abatement or particular statutory damage categories. Thus, the case does not provide authority for the specific proposition listed.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that the judge erred in granting summary judgment for the defendant on the plaintiffs’ claim of violation of G. L. c. 186, § 14. There must be a trial… If the defendant has taken no action or inadequate action… then the plaintiffs will be entitled to judgment, appropriate injunctive relief, costs and reasonable attorney’s fees. See G. L. c. 186, § 14.”

*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.proposition: Massachusetts law imposes a legal obligation on landlords to maintain habitable rental premises, including through the implied warranty of habitability.
*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.support_reasoning: Although this is a concurrence/dissent, Quirico, J. explicitly agrees that the traditional no-repair rule must be abandoned and that, at least for dwelling units, landlords have a legal obligation tied to habitability standards. He would ground that obligation in an implied agreement to comply with statutory and code-based minimum standards for fitness for human habitation, which is a form of implied warranty of habitability, even though he criticizes the majority’s broader formulation. Thus the opinion supports the proposition that Massachusetts law imposes a legal duty on landlords to maintain habitable premises through an implied habitability commitment.
*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.relevant_excerpt: “I agree with the majority of the court that, at least as to dwelling units, the time has come to reconsider the rule so long imbedded in our law of landlord and tenant that ‘[t]here is no implied agreement, apart from fraud, that the demised premises are or will continue to be fit for occupancy or safe and in good repair….’ … I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards, and (b) that by renting such a unit the landlord impliedly agrees….”}

*Ducey v. Doherty*, 459 Mass. 222, 229 (.proposition: The inability to access hot water for daily needs constitutes a serious breach of habitability standards, for which Plaintiff may recover damages.

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 100 (1.proposition: Defendant’s failure to adequately address the loss of hot water, even after being notified multiple times, is an actionable breach under M.G.L. c. 186, § 14.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 100 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion does interpret and apply G.L. c. 186, § 14, but the facts and holding concern repeated sewage flooding and sanitary violations, not loss of hot water or a landlord’s failure to restore hot water after notice. The court holds that Gem’s reckless failure to prevent repeated flooding interfered with quiet enjoyment and was actionable under § 14, including attorneys’ fees, but it does not address hot water or use that as the predicate breach. Thus, citing this case specifically for failure to address loss of hot water as an actionable § 14 breach is inaccurate, though it does generally support that serious failures to provide essential services/sanitary conditions can be actionable under § 14.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 100 (1.relevant_excerpt: “In sum, we hold that a tenant need not seek a criminal conviction before claiming damages under G. L. c. 186, § 14. Nor must the tenant prove that the landlord intended to interfere with the tenant’s rights, at least as long as the landlord’s conduct was reckless. Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to damages for the unnecessary expenses incurred and for the diminution in value of her rental unit during the period of interference.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with contract-based rent abatement as the measure of damages for breach of the implied warranty of habitability, not with a broader measure that includes “unnecessary expenses incurred” plus “diminution in value” of the rental unit. The court explicitly notes that, apart from the timing question, damages are not in dispute and adopts the standard ‘difference between the value of the apartment as warranted and the rental value of the apartment in its defective condition.’ It does not discuss or authorize additional consequential expenses beyond this abatement measure, so it does not support the proposition as stated.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.relevant_excerpt: “The trial judge found that the measure of damages was ‘the difference between the value of the apartment as warranted and the rental value of the apartment in its defective condition.’ See McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304, 306 (1977). Apart from the question whether the tenant’s rent abates only after the landlord has had a reasonable time to repair, damages are not in dispute in this case.”

*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Defendant’s continued delay violates the reasonable expectations of a tenant regarding habitable living conditions.
*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion discusses habitability only in terms of assessing the amount of damages for breach of the warranty of habitability and notes that most conditions had minimal impact and that the landlord was fairly responsive. It does not address any ‘continued delay’ by the landlord, nor does it articulate a principle that delay in making repairs violates the tenant’s reasonable expectations of habitable conditions. The case therefore does not stand for the specific proposition stated.
*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “Several violations of the State Sanitary Code…have existed in the tenant’s apartment since Young and his mother acquired the property. The judge concluded, however, that most of the conditions had minimal impact on the use and enjoyment of the apartment and that Young had been fairly responsive to the tenant’s requests for repairs. … The judge properly could have disregarded the minor code violations.”
